pull.title: net: simplify PONG handler
pull.body:
We treat a buffer size mismatch as a protocol violation.
We treat a zero microsecond pong response as spurious (likely the local clock is broken).

rename.from: net: Simplify PONG handler, improve readability of the processing logic.
rename.to: net: simplify PONG handler and disconnect for protocol violations

events.body:
Is this intended as a pure refactoring or does the change come with any intentional change in behaviour?

Is the change from `nAvail >= sizeof(nonce)` to `nAvail != sizeof(nonce)` intentional?
@practicalswift the change is intentional, the buffer should exactly match the expected length (yes i know this means we cant extend the pong message in the future)
@pstratem Thanks for clarifying! Any other intentional deviations from a pure refactoring? :-)

events.message: Simplify PONG handler, improve readability of the processing logic.

events.body: @practicalswift the timing constraint is changed from > to >= as it's measured in microseconds. a ping time of zero seconds is almost certainly in error.
and obviously the error messages are changed to be more specific

rename.from: net: simplify PONG handler and disconnect for protocol violations

events.body: @pstratem did you want to follow up and address any comments here?
Closing, as this has been waiting for author for more than a month. Let me know if you want to reopen this.

comments.body: maybe "received pong before or at time ping sent"
Instead of adding a comment here, we could make the LogPrint more informative (which would self comment the code).

Is this intentional?  sizeof should return 8 (is 8 intentional here) but we might have side effects depending on the OS.
Why use sizeof here and not >0 or just nonce?
